sentence: Lumber Liquidators Holdings, Inc.' s LL CEO Robert.
M. Lynch has quit "unexpectedly" without any explanation leading to almost 17% drop in the company's share price yesterday.
Lynch's resignation being the second high profile departure in the last three weeks, after CFO Daniel Terrell announced to step down in June, has added to the company's troubles.
Thomas Sullivan, founder of Lumber Liquidators will now be the acting CEO while John M. Presley, the company's lead independent director, will serve as board of directors' non-executive chairman.
Lynch will no longer be a part of the Lumber Liquidators board.

Lumber Liquidators has been in trouble following a report aired on 60 Minutes on Mar 1, accusing the company of selling laminates, mostly sourced from China, containing formaldehyde levels that do not meet California emissions standards.
Share price of the company has fallen over 59.3% since the allegations first surfaced.
Earlier in May, the company suspended sale of these products until board committee finished assessment of its sourcing compliance program.
The development surfaced a week after the company stated that the U.S. Department of Justice is likely to press criminal charges over the carcinogenic laminates.
Nevertheless, Lumber Liquidators continues to vehemently deny all the charges and has blamed the whole thing on short sellers.
This assurance, however, has failed to pacify investors and environmentalists alike and the company is facing significant challenges on the legal front.
It has already been slapped with over 100 lawsuits that seek class action status.
Though the company has initiated free air quality tests, many argue that it shows formaldehyde content in air and not in the laminates.
The company has already spent over $2.3 million in providing air quality tests, and with so many lawsuits the legal charges are expected to mount if things take an adverse turn for the company.
The controversy could not have come at a worst time for Lumber Liquidators.
The company's performance over the last four quarters is nothing short of dismal with the results missing the Zacks Consensus Estimate in the trailing four quarters by an average of 80.6%.
In the most recent quarter, the company's posted negative surprise of 293.3%.
Analysts observe that things are going to get worse before they get better at Lumber Liquidators and expect a cloud of uncertainty over the company remaining fiscal performance.

It seems that Lumber Liquidators' troubles might prove to be advantageous for other home improvement retailer's such as Lowe's Companies Inc. LOW , The Home Depot, Inc. HD and Tile Shop Holdings, Inc. TTS .
